>>91502909
the primary subject tends to be the first thing mentioned in the prompt that it recognizes
so with your prompt it's primarily going to be concerned with emma watson, hermione, and it being a masterpiece

it probably doesn't recognize any "masterpieces" of violinists, and certainly not any emma watson or hermione pics with violins

try starting with "a musician playing the violin"

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Is there a way to check if you have lingering random files not used on archlinux? I have a very minimal install but I worry that there are little crumbs scattered everywhere that need to be taken care of

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91488400
kek

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91498861
A file just sitting there isn't going to do anything so you might as well ignore it unless it takes up a considerable amount of space.

The way to check is to see if any package owns the file:
$ pacman -Fl $(pacman -Qq) > /tmp/filelist 2>/dev/null
$ find /etc -type f -not -name "*.pac*" -print0 | xargs -0 -r -I{} /bin/sh -c 'grep -q -F -- {} /tmp/filelist ||  echo {}'


Any of those files are candidates that could be removed. They could also be files created at startup or during normal operation of an application so you need to go through them one-by-one.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91498993
I should also mention that this doesn't work for AUR packages because they have no file list. This is where pacman is flawed compared to other package managers that keep a local database of files belonging to packages.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91499037
Thanks, I'll take a look.

I do have another question though, I noticed that after I remove some packages that configs still exist in home/.config, sure which is normal (I guess) but is there a guarantee that all actual required package files/system files are being cleaned up elsewhere?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91499062
When you remove a package it removes any files belonging to that package. Nothing is left behind.

Sometimes pacman will leave .pacsave files which backup certain files before removing them. Pacman also won't touch config files that were installed outside of the package manager's involvement (created at startup or during normal operation of the application).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91499166
They are in the same location as the file that is being backed up just search for them:
find /etc -name "*.pacsave"


There are also .pacnew files which are new versions of files that pacman doesn't automatically merge.

pacdiff -f -o

posts.com:
My current system has the entire file system on one partition. I want to put my home directory on a separate partition. I already have a drive I want to use for this purpose but it has data on it that I want to keep.
If I mount this separate partition as /home will I lose what is already on this partition?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91499962
You can't use the same mount point for two different devices, if that's what you're asking.
Try mounting it to a temporary location first, offloading the data you want to keep, then repurposing it as your /home. Keep in mind you'll need to update your fstab. If you run into file ownership or directory permissions problems, chown the /home/user directory as your user

ITT, we discuss alternative operating systems and alternative ISA.

We discuss alternatives to Windows, Mac and Linux, such as SerenityOS, Haiku, GNU/HURD, AmigaOS/AROS, NT for PowerPC, and rare BSDs, as well homebrew projects and operating system development.
We also we discuss non-x86 ISAs from the past (6502, 68000, Alpha, Itanium, PA-RISC, PowerPC, SuperH, VAX, Z80, PDP-11), the present (ARM, MIPS, POWER, SPARC) and the future (RISC-V, OpenPOWER).

You can also ask here for more information. Don't forget to check out the wiki, by the way!

>AIG Wiki: https://wiki.installgentoo.com/wiki//aig/_Alternative_ISA_General
>AOSG wiki: https://wiki.installgentoo.com/wiki//aosg/_Alternative_Operating_System_General

I've started writing an NT-like kernel. Won't be a clone, this isn't ReactOS (and anyway ReactOS is not the most true clone either.)
I might implement a small semblance of binary compatibility, enough for simplistic native mode or Win32 console programs to run, but not much more, and certainly not driver compatibility. It all depends on how much effort it would require.
I do envisage implementing basic Subsystem for Unix-like Applications, so I can run my GCC and programs like that. I will avoid annoying shit like signals as much as I can, I realise in practice they will probably become a necessity.
This will be a fun project. I wrote a Unix-like 3 years ago - it was about as feature-rich as Xv6, with a few simple programs ported like Ash shell. It was also as buggy as fuck because I didn't know what I was doing.
And since we're /aig/ too now apparently, I will even try to get this thing working on at least one non-x64 platform. Probably RISC-V or AArch64.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91475223
It's not that I love ARM
It's that I hate fans and any kind of noise, and love small, simple things. I like efficiency and tinkerability and neatness.

The idea of a small, silent box that does the simple things I actually use my computer for well and is unconcerned with anything else appeals to me on multiple levels.

Desktop computers are so ungainly and inelegant, laptops are generally noisy and restrictive, and are cumbersome in their own way. Things like the Raspberry Pi and other SBCs and kludgy devices like the Pinebook Pro and repurposed old media equipment like modded games consoles or hacked TV streaming sticks are just inherently appealing to me

X86_64 is a bloated, dying leviathan at this point, RISC is the future, Apple Silicon and the various ARM microprocessors powering Android and SBCs point the way, but its not there yet in non walled garden personal computing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91475468
I can get that. I hate fans too and I have a big suspicion sleeping in my younger years in a room with a very fan-y computer is what gave me tinnitus.

I got a Node202 and put a Core i5-13500 into it. Noctua fan. I literally have to hold my ear to the exhaust to hear it in normal operation and that fucker is faster than I need. I bought a small monitor (about Macbook Air size and same resolution/picture quality) and placed it on top of it. Like a Classical desktop computer. I sit in front of it like in the days of old. Getting to this setup was way more expensive than I'm willing to admit, but it was possible. I wasted a lot of money and time on utterly unsatisfying ARM computers before that.

Otherwise you could look into a convertible 2-in-1, (basically x86 tablets) remove the (usually shitty) keyboard, put it on a small tablet stand with additional usb hub and put a nicer, proper keyboard in front of it. Get a more recent one with a core i5 kaby lake and not only will it be fanless, it'll also run circles around any ARM SBC you can get while being cheaper and maybe even using less power than aformentioned ARM.

I can guarantee you any permutation of these options will make you happier than any ARM ever will. It's up to you to tinker and do research to find out what's best for you. Don't be afraid of unconventional solutions.

>>91501529
It's part of the contract you the programmer make with the language.

https://llvm.org/docs/LangRef.html#function-attributes
>This attribute indicates that the function is required to return, unwind, or interact with the environment in an observable way e.g. via a volatile memory access, I/O, or other synchronization. The mustprogress attribute is intended to model the requirements of the first section of [intro.progress] of the C++ Standard. As a consequence, a loop in a function with the mustprogress attribute can be assumed to terminate if it does not interact with the environment in an observable way, and terminating loops without side-effects can be removed. If a mustprogress function does not satisfy this contract, the behavior is undefined.

Detecting this in general would imply a solution to the Halting problem. If that were possible, the clause wouldn't even be necessary. Nevertheless, there's a open bug to detect simple cases like the one in the OP
https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/issues/56819

The issue here isn't the unused function. It's that clang removes the (generated) return statement from main because it sees that it can never reach the end of main but it then sees that the infinite loop doesn't do anything. So what happens is that the main function ends and just continues executing code after main, which happens to be the next function. The issue here is that clang optimizes code out of order without dependency check.

yes it is compatible with coreboot, libreboot is preconfigured coreboot which doesnt include any proprietary spyware blobs, you are gonna need spi programmer to install it
>Anything i should watch out for when buying these things besides the obvious (functional keyboard, trackpad, battery etc)?
most of the offers you will find will still have original battery, which are going to be at like 20% of their life today, so i recommend finding unused original battery to put into it. most what i would pay attention is the actual condition
>How hard is it to get this thing up and running? I'm not new to computers (built my first one in 2014), but i have never used linux or messed around with the internals of a laptop, it'll be my first one in fact.
if you are gonna be upgrading just ram and ssd, 5 minutes
if you are gonna be additionally installing libreboot, ~30 mins more

additionally with t400 you can upgrade to quad core cpu (but better cpu wont really matter with your use case)

if you are gonna decide to install libreboot, i recommend trisquel as linux distro, as it follows libreboot and fsf ideology. the only extra step using libreboot and trisquel is having to replace the wifi card with free software one

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91499776
Picrel isn't genuine. DbContext is a config file for your database, so you don't add a new DbContext per table, CRUD Razor is nonsense, PersonController is a list of endpoints for your api (which exists everywhere), you don't need an IRepository if your app is so simple. If you want to segregate your querying logic it makes sense to have it. The person's model is just the person's class and the rules you want to apply to its properties. The PersonServices is unnecessary unless you have services specific to this entity and is only a design choice.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91499776
Never wrote UIs in C# but this look no different than backend. The thing is, in a webapi, you could (and should if your app is small) only have a DbContext, a Model (with the classes of your tables), and a Controller (with all the code).

If you want to make something more maintainable and that scales well and if your app is complex to a certain extent it's better if you separate your querying code and anything that communicates with external services in Repositories. It makes sense to have Services for the reusable functions that you might use (like VerifyPhoneNumber()), it makes sense to do CQRS and to have a Mediator.

>>91499776
It's required on large projects when TDD is mandatory.
>ViewModel for your component logic, can be tested separately;
>ViewModel (designtime) show UI data on VS designer;
>Repository layer, db abstraction, shouldn't be on frontend projects;
>Services layer, complex domain logic using repositories, access APIs;
>DbContext ORM class, shouldn't be on frontend project either.
That's standard architecture on enterprise software using Microsoft stack.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91502907
We already have that, trying to solve security issues at the network level is fundamentally the wrong approach anyways because there are simply too many ingress and egress points in most modern networks (Unless they're exceptionally locked down) to actually effectively protect all of them regardless of if you're using AI or traditional techniques, and also "network connection" = "a client" is fundamentally a bad assumption. Generally most modern security focuses more on identity than networks.

The AI you're using to monitor the connection is in itself another means of attacking things because if it has the capability to cut any sus clients you can misuse those same capabilities to brick an entire network, by for instance spoofing the connections of a legitimate user to trick the AI into blocking legitimate users.

Also every argument you can make in terms of AI magically solving issues when it comes to defensive cybersecurity ignores that attackers use AI too so even if your AI does dramatically increase security dramatically increased security isn't fucking enough because of how fucking bad things are.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91502907
>>91503082
Also generally, how do you train the AI on what is and isn't "sus" to begin with? What is "sus"?

The solarwinds hack involved the Russians breaking into a software company, compromising their software supply chain, having people install this software from the official software repositories, and then sending the data back through the normal customer feedback stuff. How the fuck is an AI supposed to figure out if that's "sus"? AI's aren't magic, there is actual limitations to how they function, if they're sensitive enough to flip out over that, they are going to throw a ton of false positives.

The foundation of security isn't having some AI or human going around watching for threats and shutting them down, because by the time you shut down the threat it's often already too late. It's having systems which are well administered and managed where you don't even need to detect attacks because they won't get through. Detection is intrinsically a half-measure and a bandaid in isolation.

Users of all levels welcome.
Share Windows tools, utilities, tips & tricks.

FAQ:
>How do I activate Windows?
https://github.com/massgravel/Microsoft-Activation-Scripts
HWID mimics upgrade activation to generate a permanent legitimate license. (works on non-VL editions only)

>>Which W10 version should I install?
>Home/Pro
Comes with bloatware apps (games, music, news, etc) and bloatware system apps
>Education/Workstation/Enterprise
Comes with bloatware system apps (weather, people, onedrive, teams, etc).
>LTSC (5 years support, VL/KMS only) / IoT LTSC (10 years support, HWID only)
Comes with Win32 system utils, no MS Store, no apps. It's basically W10: W7 Edition
If you need MS Store, run this in cmd: wsreset -i
Install Xbox/Gamebar apps for feature parity with other versions.

>Do I even need IoT LTSC?
W10 Home/Pro/Edu/Ent editions end support in 2025, LTSC in 2027, IoT LTSC in 2032.

>How do I activate Office?
https://github.com/abbodi1406/KMS_VL_ALL_AIO/releases
Emulates a KMS server, not ideal as KMS can trip your AV and deactivate. Alternatively, use MSOffice through your browser since it's free.
Or you can try OnlyOffice/LibreOffice and set it to save as MSOffice file formats.

>Where can I get Windows/Office ISOs?
https://massgrave.dev/genuine-installation-media.html
Other sources:
https://pastebin.com/p6b3N9w2

>Should I debloat or Optimize-Offline?
If you need to ask, then no. You WILL break something.
If you know what you're doing:

https://pastebin.com/Zh7WSbJ2

https://pastebin.com/hN8nnwns

>Make 4chan/fwt easier to browse
https://www.4chan-x.net

OpenShell/RetroBar/WinClassic/StartIsBack

No.

As payment I have some useful windows programs.

OpenRGB - Open source RGB manager
Dopamine - Material themed local music player
Portmaster - Open source DNS firewall. Can be set up to block trackers, ads and malicious internet addresses.
Bloatbox - Open source windows debloater. Removes windows bloat programs like the candy crush shit and a bunch of other programs no one uses.
Fan Control - Open source fan control program.
TaskBarX - Open source task bar theme program. Can make windows 10 task bars look like 11, make the bar see through or completely transparent. Bunch of other things too.
System Informer - Not process hacker. You need to search this one up. This is the updated version of process hacker. Better task manager. It's on Sourceforge no the github version.
FxSound - Open source equalizer and sound panel. Works great out of the box using the general sound preset.
Jpeg view - Open source windows photo replacement. Great image viewer. Very minimalist with a very significant amount of features.
Pinta - Open source MS Paint alternative. Just better in everyway while still being simple. Only complaint I have is it does not have a dark mode.
Peazip - Open source better looking 7zip. But 7zip is fine too.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91502734
Managed to solve it by myself.
The solution was to create the command under
\HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\*\shell[\code]
then in the key with the name of the command you just add a string called AppliesTo with 
System.Kind:"video"

in it. Most video file types are correctly associated with this System.Kind, I assume that if they aren't all you need to do is go to (using xvid as an example):
Computer\HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\.xvid

then you edit its PerceivedType string (or create it) and add "video" as its value. Maybe you also have to add a string called "Content Type" with "video/xvid" in it, I'm not sure.
I don't know whether you can create custom file kinds but that solves my problem for now.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>91498948
>With the PCIe shit I could somewhat understand why boards are lacking, probably because they're trying to go for 5.0 and increased speed means signal integrity from the CPU to the slot matters a lot more than it did with slower PCIe versions
That's one of the rationalizations but it's not concrete.
What determines your PCB materials isn't just the signaling requirements but also the distance. A desktop motherboard has less requirements than some server boards which can half a meter long and could be bringing PCIe to a backplane or riser. You might need Megatron 6 for a server but a desktop board can get away with a higher loss material depending on how competent your PCB trace layout is.
>that could require PCIe redrivers/retimers
Everyone talked about that but they don't actually exist on desktop boards or at the very least aren't used for the main CPU PCIe slots.
Whoever came up with boards needing that shit must of heard it from someone mentioning it in the context of servers which DO need redrivers/retimers depending on where PCIe signals are headed.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Don't get me started on these massive smartphones that barely fit in your pocket! What's the point of having a phone that's almost as big as a tablet? It's uncomfortable to hold, inconvenient to carry around, and not to mention, it's just plain ridiculous.

And to make matters worse, many newer phones don't even have a headphone jack! How are we supposed to listen to music or watch videos without a wired connection? Sure, wireless earbuds are an option, but they're expensive and can be easy to lose. Not to mention, they often have a shorter battery life than traditional wired headphones.

And don't even get me started on the fact that some phones don't have a microSD slot. This means that you're stuck with the amount of storage that comes with the phone, and you can't expand it with an external memory card. It's frustrating, to say the least, especially if you like to take a lot of photos or store music and movies on your phone.

In short, it's disappointing that phone manufacturers are sacrificing practicality for design, and it seems like the consumer's needs are taking a back seat. It's time to prioritize function over form and bring back the features that make smartphones truly convenient and user-friendly.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>91500978
It's fine as long as they are on separate drives. They'll never interreact, only the Grub menu will detect them both, allowing you to choose which to boot.
You only face potential problems If you stupidly attempt to boot them from the same dive. Windows updates will try to nuke Linux, and Linux might eat away/corrupt you Windows install.
Keep them separate.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91501128
That is exactly what I did. Windows installed on one SSD, Linux Mint installed on another (albeit sharing the drive with some general purpose NTFS storage).

All of a sudden, my browsers on Windows forgot how to save history. Also my Wireguard VPN client stopped working, if I connect to a VPN through the Wireguard client, Windows thinks I'm not connected at all.

I tried to create a separate EFI partition for the Mint installation on the Mint SSD and assigned Mint to use it for boot files, but apparently the Ubuntu installer doesn't care and just uses the Windows boot manager anyway. That is the only part of my Mint installation on the Windows SSD, the boot files, and it's because the installer overrode my choice.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91501237
>I tried to create a separate EFI partition for the Mint installation on the Mint SSD and assigned Mint to use it for boot files, but apparently the Ubuntu installer doesn't care and just uses the Windows boot manager anyway. That is the only part of my Mint installation on the Windows SSD, the boot files, and it's because the installer overrode my choice
Sounds like you already found your problem.
You should have disconnected the Windows drive when setting up the Mint drive. After setting everything up, tell the Bios to boot from the Mint drive first. After reconnecting the Windows drive Grub will detect it and add it to the list. Now you have everything properly separated.

Then your requirements are unsatisfiable, because if your goal is
>I want to damage my computer irreparably
and you impose the conditions
>I will not inflict physical hardware damage of any sort manually
>I do not have access to software capable of damaging my hardware, and
>I will not count the absolute and permanent removal of all existing software as fulfilling the task
Then you have no means of fulfilling the task, because the above that exhaustively eliminates hardware destruction, software causing hardware destruction, or software destruction - and since the machine's hardware and software are untouched, so is the machine.

posts.com:
The best beginner distro is the one you choose to try Linux first on. If you want to learn Linux quickly I unironically recommend Gentoo, since you will very quickly learn how to do common tasks from CLI just by following the Handbook.

If your goal isn't to "learn Linux", mint is fine if you don't care about how you are going to upgrade in a year, and Mint/PopOS/Ubuntu will enable a lot of bad habits that will bite your ass down the line like adding external repos, sudo make install, running github scripts etc that Debian users know are bad ideas.

Debian is a good beginner distro if you read the handbook beforehand and go in with an open mind. Nowadays when I introduce my friends to Linux it's less "Is this person technically minded?" When deciding which Distro for them but more "Does this person have an open-mind to learn how to do things differently" when deciding Mint vs Debian.

I wouldn't recommend it to someone who's an utter beginner to Linux, but it's a very good distro.

Yes, you do need to install the Nvidia Driver. The OS will attempt to load it automatically, and chances are, it'll work. "Nouveau" is pronounced as "no video", so don't install that. I'd suggest the proprietary Nvidia drivers.
Note that the latest driver may not always work. Nvidia Optimus applet should tell you which GPU is in usage. If you see the Intel GPU being used even in performance mode, consult Mint forums or subreddit to learn which driver is the best for your specific GPU. Chances are it'll work perfectly after installing the correct driver.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91501609
>Does anyone still use it?

The concept intrigued me but it was buggy and slow as hell, spent years waiting for it to be properly stable.
Now I find it 100% usable.

The UI and its features are the main selling point, at this point I can't go back to a regular browser. The sidebar is extremely useful, it basically turns entire sites into small widgets you can access instantly without opening dedicated tabs. I use it for shit like translators, character counter/writing tools, internet archives, piracy sites and so on.
Bookmarks, history and downloads are managed differently and they have their own quick menu on the left.
The browser natively integrates shit like RSS feed, mail, notes, activities, calendar and so on, so you can get rid of dedicated software on your desktop.

Lots of features seem unnecessary at first but getting used to them actually improves the workflow (stuff like tab stacking/groups, instant tab splitscreen, the custom screencap button, CSS debugger etc). None of it is revolutionary by itself but it's nice to have it all integrated without the need of a hundred extensions, it all works seamlessly together.
Fuck, you can setup shortcuts and even mouse gestures for fucking everything, making everything quicker.

It takes 40 minutes to try everything and set up the whole thing but if you take the time, you can really create the best possible browsers for your tastes and needs.

>>91493341
if you feel the code is too convoluted, "stop, drop and roll".
Stop: don't add features for a while, focus on fixing the code.
Drop: either refactor or rewrite the code. Yes, rewriting 50k lines is sometimes very worthwhile. It won't take even remotely as long as last time because you don't lose anything you learned doing this work, you no longer have to experiment between different options and parameters as you know what's good for you, etc.
Roll: given that you now know your needs better, use the opportunity to reroll the architecture to better fit your actual requirement.

posts.com:
I'm kind of confused as to why OOP is regarded as a bad thing; it seems like a nice way to lay out a program. In my game engine, for example, I have a Camera class. This class is fed inputs from the event handler (which gets them from SDL) and processes them. The Camera is responsible for things like interpolating the current and next position, or limiting its travel (so you can't, say, zoom out indefinitely), or handling world wraparound. The Camera can be queried for a view matrix and a projection matrix. This seems a lot more logical than just having a bunch of free-floating functions to do those things, but maybe I'm missing something.

Or for an even more pronounced example: the renderer. The renderer does a ton of stuff under the hood, but from the user's perspective all they have to do is give it render objects and/or meshes. All the complicated business of uploading stuff to the GPU, batching meshes, culling, etc., is tucked away and doesn't need to be looked at or thought about when you aren't specifically changing any of those renderer features. This seems like a really good thing to me because it means when you don't actually need to deal with those parts of the program, they're self-contained and inaccessible and not getting in your way, making the parts you do need to interact with (eg, "here's an object and its mesh & material settings") much more simple.

I don't know, maybe there's an angle I'm missing here, but I don't see why OOP is regarded as a bad thing, it seems like a good way to segregate different parts of your program.

Well, I wouldn't say that everything about OOP is good or that it has no bad parts. For example when it comes to processing a ton of data it's probably better to organize things in a data-oriented manner (albeit, within the context of OOP, because data-oriented code is often unintuitive and better to encapsulate where possible, so that the containing class can manage the logic). OOP isn't perfect, and there are areas where other paradigms should be used or adhered to. Data-oriented programming is often a good way to process lots of data. Functional programming's idea of making as many things const as possible is a good idea. OOP isn't the end-all and be-all.

But at the same time you can't claim things like inheritance are OOP, when inheritance blatantly violates encapsulation (your class suddenly has parts that are controlled externally, via the class it inherits from - this is the opposite of what OOP is about). Or worse, claim that inheritance, which isn't even OOP, is somehow what OOP is all about. That's just retarded.

>>91499614
You can't partially instantiate a template type, the whole template has to be instantiated. You can't have a Foo<int> type with just one member function disabled. It would have to look like this:
#include <type_traits>

template <typename T>
class Foo
{
  public:
  Foo(int i) {}

  template <typename U, typename = std::enable_if_t< std::is_same_v<U, float> > >
  Foo() {}

};

Foo<int> Bar()
{
  return 5;
}

I don't think you quite get it. A template is not actually code, it's just an instruction for the compiler to generate a class at compile time by substituting all of the template arguments you give it in to the placeholders. If the template argument substitution cannot be done then the instantiation for that argument is cancelled. If after all of the instantiations have been generated your type cannot be found then that's a compile error.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The free version of vital is slimed down. Not really a problem but you will hit early its limitations. But it does what it does and for being free, it does it damn good. This is not the contra here, actual a postive point.

Where the contra points comes in is, the online connectivity, the subcription model and the limitation of presets hiden behind a paywall (your account).
From the VST it connects to your online account, and only from there you can add new presets. There are Forks for linux of an older version (the one matt gave out for free) that remove the always dial home script and online features. But its very convoluted on the linux distros/github.

I wouldn't say Vital is "THE" Best free plugin, since it isn't really free. You still have to pay with your data, and even the than, the free version is slimed down. It does a very good job as a VST and i can see why people like it so much.

People need to stop call it Open Source, only the alpha version was released by matt as open source. And its actual halffree.

Users of all levels welcome. Share Windows tools, utilities, tips & tricks.

FAQ:
>How do I activate Windows?
https://github.com/massgravel/Microsoft-Activation-Scripts
HWID mimics upgrade activation to generate a permanent legitimate license. (works on non-VL editions only)

>Which W10 version should I install?
Home/Pro: No, comes with bloatware apps (games, music, news, etc) and bloatware system apps.
Education/Workstation/Enterprise: Yes, but comes with bloatware system apps (weather, people, onedrive, teams, etc).
LTSC (5 years support, VL/KMS only) / IoT LTSC (10 years support, HWID only): Yes, but comes with Win32 system utils, limited system apps like Settings and Notification area, no MS Store. If you need MS Store, run this in cmd: wsreset -i
Install Xbox/Gamebar apps for feature parity with other versions.

>Do I even need IoT LTSC?
W10 Home/Pro/Edu/Ent editions end support in 2025, LTSC in 2027, IoT LTSC in 2032.

>How do I activate Office?
https://github.com/abbodi1406/KMS_VL_ALL_AIO/releases
Emulates a KMS server, not ideal as KMS can trip your AV and deactivate. Alternatively, use MSOffice through your browser since it's free.
Or you can try OnlyOffice/LibreOffice and set it to save as MSOffice file formats.

>Where can I get Windows/Office ISOs?
https://massgrave.dev/genuine-installation-media.html
Other sources:
https://pastebin.com/p6b3N9w2

>Should I debloat or Optimize-Offline?
If you need to ask, then no. You WILL break something. If you know what you're doing:

OpenShell/RetroBar/WinClassic/StartIsBack

>>91467732
I use a bunch of different brands across my 5 or so inked pens:
>PIlot Iroshizuku
I like the colour choice and the price isn't too bad. The bottle is also well-designed since it's narrow and the ink level won't get too shallow unless it's really low.
>Sailor Kiwaguro
This is my only pigmented ink. Only reason I settled for Sailor's is because I got it for really cheap back when there was a big sale.
>Parker Quink Black
What can I say? It's cheap and does its job. Hard to complain about it, really. Probably the cheapest ink I have in my collection.
>Graf von Faber-Castell
Bought this out of curiosity. It's good but I can't exactly recommend it unless you're a richfag. They're kinda overpriced. Even Montblanc inks are cheaper, I think. But their one advantage is that most of the inks in the GvFC line are indelible, but then again how important are indelible ink? It's not like I'll be signing cheques often, or keeping journals that I want to archive.

There is one brand of inks I'm curious about: PenBBS inks. Have yet to try them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91490588
I don't claim to be the most consistent with it but consistent offloading and review has changed me fundamentally in the same way spells of semi-regular mindfulness meditation sessions have changed me. Something is different and I couldn't begin to explain the extent of it or the parts I can't personally see at this time---I can see that with continued use, I will be able to point out exactly what it does in time. It's like a dram of scotch on a miserable day, it changes you for the better in subtle ways you can't expect.

Specifically, after some trial and error, you cease assigning importance and value to some errant thoughts you once took as "yours" and follow new paths. You find patterns. Most noticeable for me was becoming more cognizant and organized with thoughts and how I put them down, how I remember them and shape them. Even a grocery list is a feedback loop that gets picked apart; a lot of this is unconscious and you just notice something one day and change it with little thought. Regular writing like this is an intersection of mindfulness yoga and depth psychology in a very novel way. It's making the unconscious conscious and open for review but also working top down where things organize themselves without psychodrama or much awareness that it happened. Then you write that down too.

Yeah, writing and reflecting, however brief and benign, is absolutely cosmic in effect on the same level of the work put in. It's some real lead a horse to water shit and this horse don't like to drink water for months at a time, but the results are profound, especially when you write that down too.

posts.com:
I’d just like to interject for a moment. What you’re refering to as Linux, is in fact, GNU/LInux, or as I’ve recently taken to calling it, GNU plus Linux. Linux is not an operating system unto itself, but rather another free component of a fully functioning GNU system made useful by the GNU corelibs, shell utilities and vital system components comprising a full OS as defined by POSIX.

Many computer users run a modified version of the GNU system every day, without realizing it. Through a peculiar turn of events, the version of GNU which is widely used today is often called “Linux”, and many of its users are not aware that it is basically the GNU system, developed by the GNU Project.

There really is a Linux, and these people are using it, but it is just a part of the system they use. Linux is the kernel: the program in the system that allocates the machine’s resources to the other programs that you run. The kernel is an essential part of an operating system, but useless by itself; it can only function in the context of a complete operating system. Linux is normally used in combination with the GNU operating system: the whole system is basically GNU with Linux added, or GNU/Linux. All the so-called “Linux” distributions are really distributions of GNU/Linux.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91487974
>>91487187
I've got it, thanks! I had a really annoying typo that made me doubt my knowledge of basic maths.
;; Even indexes
(make-shared-array vec (λ (i) (list (* 2 i)))
               (+ (modulo (car dims) 2)
              (quotient (car dims) 2)))
;; Odd Indexes
(make-shared-array vec (λ (i) (list (+ 1 (* 2 i))))
                (quotient (car dims) 2))


It is really cool to think that a language as simple as scheme has arrays by reference and arbitrary indexing. You can slice arrays anyway you want as long as it is in a affine linear way. This is really cool stuff since this is the bread and butter of matlab and R, which are much more complex. Their syntax is really less verbose, but scheme tends of the wordy side of things right

>>91483010
Other TTS models and AI TTS Overview and videos
https://pastebin.com/VcREHHWT

>Tortoise TTS stack: Learn what it does. Suggest improvements. Compare it to 11 labs.
1) Autoregressive transformer stack predicts discrete speech "tokens" given a text prompt. (Like DALLE using GPT but with speech)
2) CLIP model judges autoregressive transformer outputs against the text ranking the most probable.
3) Speech tokens are decoded into a low-quality MEL spectrogram using a VQVAE.
4) UNet diffusion model decodes VQVAE output into raw audio wav file using openAI ImprovedDiffusion.
>Tortoise is basically OpenAI's DALLE, applied to speech data.

There are over 400 tortoise tts forks available
If you find code improvements or good features, report back
https://github.com/neonbjb/tortoise-tts/network/members

CLIP Explained: Contrastive Language Image Pretraining
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=T9XSU0pKX2E
VQVAE Explained - Vector Quantized Variational Auto-Encoders
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VZFVUrYcig0
Linking Unet, CLIP and VAE together

Training AI models is time consuming and GPU intensive. This is the only way to keep up with the costs and resource requirements of training for individual users. This is where we got up to last threads talking about P2P Distributed Training
>Hivemind: Decentralized deep learning in PyTorch (Lightning wrappers available)
https://github.com/learning-at-home/hivemind
>Hivemind is explicitly for training from scratch
>Pytorch_lightning provides hivemind wrappers when designing your own models,
>Retrofit training uses hivemind directly.
Petal
https://github.com/bigscience-workshop/petals
>aka BLOOMZ is a model implementing hivemind's DHT.
>Allowing you to run the model collaboratively by running the model in 8GB chunk

posts.com:
>>91469675
I'm just a single Engineer with some experience doing technical interviews so take my advice with a grain of salt, but personally, I'd trim down the "resume words" like "contributed" and "enabling." Maybe it's just me, but they're invitations for the reader to zone out before they get to the actual technical descriptions that describe your specific experience/expertise. You have a technical resume with technical qualifications, no need to soften it.

>Worked in an Industrial IoT environment which remotely managed a connected network of industrial devices.
>Worked with clients to create and modernize sensor grids using a PaaS platform, providing live telemetry dashboards, digital twins, cloud-to-device operations, operator defined alarms and notification rules.

>Do I need to be more specific on what kind of tools, languages, services and other stuff that I used?
I would list them separately at the bottom as a "technology worked with" kind of addendum. The technical interviewers will be interested in what specific technology you work with, but it doesn't need to be part of the narrative of what you do/did at your job.

I posted here a while back about trying to find a job after about a year as a Data Analyst and almost nothing to show for it, and managed to find a new one as an Associate Business Analyst for 3 months temp-to-hire. It took about 6 or 7 months of searching and one really good interview.

I got some advice from a guy about 20 years older than me: When asked "how do you handle a challenging problem that represents a roadblock" and the answer was just "Check documentation -> Check prior similar work -> Google it -> Ask a Coworker -> Ask the Manager". This should have been obvious but I think the takeaway here is that unless you're some shining genius, just go for generic but confident answers on common questions, and not waffling on questions when you don't know or only have training as an answer.

>>91475454
>currently the two wlan router have their own wifi network but i want to combine them into one so that you dont have to manually switch the network on the phone or whatever.
Not sure what you mean by network in this context. A separate IP network? So the extra one is in router mode? Switch it to access point mode so you'll be having one single Ethernet block.
Network as in the name the WiFi has? Yes, you can name both the same and set the same password.
>mesh
>WDS
Forget all that, it's not relevant to you as they are on the same wired backbone.
>i still have either two separately named SSIDs that i can connect to or i name them the same resulting in the old router just disappearing.
They are separate access points no matter what, you can't magically make the two boxes appear as one.
You can keep adding more of them if the coverage is not good enough, that's what they do in enterprise environments.

Both are more or less correct, don't get lost on the all the POO buzzwords.
I'll address the part I think you're caught up on: Objects don't have names, they're just values located somewhere in memory. A variable references that location -- you can have more than one variable reference the same object. Still, if you call "scans" an "object of the Scanner class" it's still perfectly idiomatic and nobody will think you're crazy.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91473504
The high conductivity on the Z axis (between the CPU and heatsink) makes up for the lackluster contact.
The graphite pads also have the quirk of having super insane conductivity on the X/Y plane, this means any heat going into the pad is spread across the pad. Heat up one edge and it will damn near instantly transfer the heat to the other edge.

This all sounds like it should be better than paste but like you said psate is just so good at filling voids and pads aren't very good.

In some cases those graphite pads can be better. I used to use Artic MX-2 but got cooler temps with the IC graphite.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91482810
It's impossible to comment on that unless you provide more information about the input and output videos.
As a rule, longer encoding = better quality and filesize. Modern codecs are very slow at encoding but provide smaller filesizes without affecting the quality very much. H264 is the most common video codec -- its encoding speed can vary from fast to slow depending on the settings, and again, going faster means bigger files with worse quality.
To encode with a different codec you just use -c:v [codec], they usually have their own options you might want to change. There's plenty of info about all that in the manual and the ffmpeg wiki https://trac.ffmpeg.org/wiki/Encode/H.265

>>91473442
Why do people get mad about electronics taking up space (power grid, networks, factories and assembly lines, servers, web services, etc.), but not the fact the same information in non-electronics like books do? Books take up considerable space in the form of plantations, wood processing plants, printers, warehouses, shelves, libraries, etc. A single book weighs sometimes half a kilogram, whereas in digital form it takes up a tiny amount in a hard drive that weighs the same. Lots of paper books just rot, whereas we are moving towards recycling at least the precious metals in electronics. They both have waste, but there's not many information technologies without waste. I guess mining can have detrimental effects that even make forestry and leaching pale in comparison.
Electricity costs for electronics are fairly minimal, considering that books need to be transported, as well as printed, cut, and bound by machinery. One Kindle Paperwhite probably wont even cost you more than a dollar in electricity over the course of charging it in its lifetime.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91486535
Your PSU emits electromagnetic noise.
Your PSU, mobo, and PC case SHOULD all be grounded (earthed) to absorb this noise so you do not hear it on your audio ports.
Your audio ports SHOULD be isolated against such noise as much as possible.
BUT--
Sometimes --either in the wiring in the walls or electrical outlets or panel, or inside the PC-- these things are done poorly or not at all.
A SUPER common example of this is the ground loop, where your PC's connection to ground (which is SUPPOSED to be free of electronic noise) has electronic noise on it.
MANY PCs have poorly isolated audio, and this is made worse if your PSU is on the bottom of the case instead of the top, because that's usually where they put the audio components on your motherboard.

TL;DR Buy a USB DAC for like $14.

SMR edition

READ THE WIKI! & help by contributing:

>NAS Case Guide. Feel free to add to it:
https://wiki.installgentoo.com/wiki/Home_server/Case_guide

/hsg/ is about learning and expanding your horizons. Know all about NAS? Learn virtualization. Spun up some VMs? Learn about networking by standing up a OPNsense/PFsense box and configuring some VLANs. There's always more to learn and chances to grow. Think you’re god-tier already? Setup OpenStack and report back.

>What software should I run?
Install Gentoo. Or whatever flavour of *nix is best for the job or most comfy for you. Jellyfin/Plex to replace Netflix, Nextcloud to replace Googlel, Ampache/Navidrome to replace Spotify, the list goes on. Look at the awesome self-hosted list and ask.

>Why should I have a home server?
/hsg/ is about learning and expanding your horizons. De-botnet your life. Learn something new. Serving applications to yourself, your family, and your frens feels good. Put your tech skills to good use for yourself and those close to you. Store their data with proper availability redundancy and backups and serve it back to them with a /comfy/ easy to use interface.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91500776
Probably not. VST instruments have existed for many years and have not replaced artists. They're used by composers as an aid in composition (because you can hear how it will sound when performed, albeit with inferior articulation) and by individuals on a budget (VSTs are expensive, but nowhere near as expensive as hiring a full orchestra to perform your soundtrack) who wouldn't be hiring musicians anyways.

Music theory itself was basically solved centuries ago; the vast majority of the best music was produced in the 17th to the early 20th century.

AI music will be used by composers as a sketchpad to get random inspiration / starting points (which, to be honest, many VSTs are already designed around), then once they have a rough idea what they want to do based off of that they'll start ripping it apart into the individual instruments, adjusting and fine-tuning it, and then, as usual, whoever contracted them will take the sheet music to an orchestra to perform.

Basically how things are right now but with more sketching tools.

It's a complicated subject but know that headphones are mostly minimum-phase and frequency response at the eardrum fully describes how something will sound, which means the time domain is irrelevant and reflections/reverb won't aid spatiality, which has been wrongly called soundstage. Soundstage actually references out-of-head localization, a literal sound stage, which happens with speakers(or any IRL sound) because of something called interaural time difference, which how sound reaches one ear before the other and interaural intensity difference, which is how the head shadow will lower the amplitude of frequencies as this happens. Also the shape of the head, mostly the outer ear, changes the frequency response of sound and gives directionality cues, without accounting for these factors constant out-of-head localization with headphones is not possible. The headstage will be 2D with only the information in the recording giving a sense of depth and location. There are some tricks to make people think something sounds more open without actually changing the sound of the headphones, like if you increase the driver distance, make the pads larger, or open the back volume to increase the audibility of external sounds.

Resolution is another thing wrongly attributed to something other than frequency response when in reality it's the higher amplitude of certain frequencies which leads to something sounding more detailed. I find the 5-10 kHz range is where this is most apparent since it can be masked by the upper midrange/treble peak if not done right.

The rest is a luxury.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>91493605
which comparisons?
png vs webp lossless is obvious here: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ju4q1WkaXT7WoxZINmQpf4ElgMD2VMlqeDN2DuZ6yJ8/edit?hl=en#gid=174429822
as for avif vs jxl consider the chromium team's tests from this point of view: https://cloudinary.com/blog/contemplating-codec-comparisons#bd_rates
according to the web almanac the median avif bitrate is around 1 bpc and jpeg is 2-3 bpc on the web, so the "oh avif is so amazing at 0.1 bpc!!" comparisons aren't representative of real world format usage and jxl tends to win at higher bpc
the decode speed for 8bpc 4:2:0 avif is actually really good right now and usually beats (or at least approaches) comparable jxl, but even that's mitigated by the decoder not decoding until the download is finished (see higher up in the last linked article); jxl tends to win at higher bpc and without subsampling

>>91495490
>>91494623
Clip requires torch and torchvision,
https://github.com/openai/CLIP/blob/main/requirements.txt
torch and torchvision uses cuda by default if I'm not mistaken.
but I can see in the pytorch github that you can disable cuda support
this guide describes a little bit about what pytorch is, and how to install it with cuda:
https://varhowto.com/install-pytorch-ubuntu-20-04/
but in this guide:
https://github.com/pytorch/pytorch
it says in the readme: "If you want to disable CUDA support, export the environment variable USE_CUDA=0. Other potentially useful environment variables may be found in setup.py."
it also says:
"if you want to compile with ROCm support, install AMD ROCm 4.0 and above installation
ROCm is currently supported only for Linux systems"
I don't know anything about that and haven't looked into it, but the support documentation for it can be found here:
https://community.amd.com/t5/knowledge-base/amd-rocm-hardware-and-software-support-document/ta-p/489937

In the pytorch readme it also says to install magma-cuda110. I'm not sure if this can be left out. I think it would have to be tested out. I can't find much documentation on this. I don't know if pytorch is dependent on cuda or if it's just convenient to use cuda with it. Idk if there are other ways to run it, as I haven't tried it out

When you install torch, torchvision and torchaudio it automatically installs cuda with it I think. At least they're installed on my system. When I do a 'pip list' in the terminal I can see that all these 3 have a version number and then +cu117 (which is cuda 11.7), and cuda is proprietary.
These cuda APIs are necessary for the install of automatic1111 webui, and I might have just installed them through that. I remember when I installed automatic1111 that it said something with cuda when the install script ran. I noticed it because I didn't have an nvidia driver installed, but only the free mesa graphics driver, so it showed an error in the install.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91463793
Let me guess, you're setting state after receiving the response? You most likely do, and that state setter function call triggers a re-render, which in turn causes yet another fetch request to be made. Solution: put your fetch call in a useEffect with an empty dep array, or preferably use a fetching lib use-swr or rtkq.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91463793
React re renders a component whenever any props or state associated with the component changes. You get a fetch request, you get your response. and then you call setState which changes the state which causes a re-render which again fires off that fetch request. useEffect is used to counteract this. I believe you're very new to react.
I highly ask you to go through the beta.reactjs.org docs once. Because it'll teach you most of the stuff you need to know, rather than going through bloated tutorials. You can still do tutorials but get into the habit of reading documentation. When you join companies nobody will be making youtube videos/tutorials for the specific niche case you want to implement. React is fun once you learn how to handle the footguns it provides.

Yeah, here's one: strings are utter garbage.
In JS they're internally encoded in UTF-16, so that's 2 * 4 * ceil(7 / 3) = 24 bytes = 192 bits to store something that could be represented using only 42 bits. And that's not including the length field and/or terminating null character, so in fact strings are even shittier than I make them out to be.

But about serverless functions, just beware of what you deploy on the edge. If you have a local database with no globalized access, deploying on the edge will actually increase the latency. Your static site & functions are very close to your users, yes, but if your database doesn't follow the same pattern of distribution, what happens is that the roadtrip between your serverless function and your db (request + response) nullifies any advantage involved in running your app on the edge.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91467427
I have a general guideline when it comes to serverless. If it's a middleware or some computing that doesn't involve a db call, serverless is good. If you're using a globally distributed database like dynamodb or cosmosdb, it's great to make your entire api serverless. However, if you're having a local database you're better off having your api as close as possible to your db server and use serverless functions only for middleware or computing tasks that don't involve database calls. The worst possible network latency you can have would be 300 to 400ms (that's the exception, not the norm). The network latency between LA & Sidney is between 40 to 50ms. That's trivial.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91468543
Well, the conventional architecture is x86 but there's a push for ARM in desktop and servers (ARM is already mainly used in mobiles). The mac computers that use m1 & m2 chips as well as the windows dev kit are ARM computers. ARM CPUs are cheaper, more power efficent and have less vulnerabilities. x86 CPUs use the CISC design and ARM uses RISC. However, ARM processors are limited in calculation capabilities compared to x86 and are not compatible with some x86 only programs. It shouldn't pose any problem for you if you use it to host your dockerized api.

The thing is they don't have direct control over the model. They can only suggest it things and try to make it work. DAN works since they've heavily prioritized that the output needs to be sterile and sanitized, but by having it say both a sterile and sanitized version and a controversial answer, it fulfills the sterile and sanitized version. The only way to fix this would be to train the AI to not say these controversial things, but this would likely lobotomize the model even more than it already is.

ProtonMail is a secure email service based in Switzerland that was founded in 2013. The company is focused on privacy and security, and it offers end-to-end encrypted email services to its users.

One of the key features of ProtonMail is its encryption system, which ensures that only the sender and recipient of an email can read its contents. The company uses a combination of client-side encryption and server-side encryption to secure the email messages. This means that even ProtonMail itself cannot access the contents of the emails stored on its servers.

ProtonMail also implements several security measures to protect the privacy of its users, including two-factor authentication, encrypted data storage, and secure email protocols such as SSL/TLS. Additionally, because the company is based in Switzerland, it is subject to strict privacy laws that protect the rights of its users.

ProtonMail offers both free and paid plans, with the paid plans providing additional features such as larger storage limits, custom domains, and priority support. The company has a large user base, including individuals, businesses, and organizations that require secure email services.

Overall, ProtonMail is a good option for people who are concerned about the privacy and security of their email communications.

>pattern/pin is also stored in the Android hardware-backed keystore (such as ARM TrustZone) since 2016, whereas apple stole this feature in 2020 (secure enclave)
Lmao no you lying motherfucker. iOS has had encryption since 2011 (iOS 14), and mandatory encryption since 2011. It’s a known problem Apple users can’t get into their phones contents without a passcode even with iCloud backed up. That’s the beauty of iOS.

Apple was a front runner in implementing some sort of encryption long before others even thought about it. Apple uses a 256-bit device-unique secret key (UID) stored in the phone’s hardware, where it’s hard to extract from. Apple says this UID is unique to the device and it doesn’t store these values. It also says that no software or hardware can read this key. This UID is mixed with the passcode to generate a new key (passcode key) to secure data on the device. Unlike Android, this UID key can’t be extracted from the device, so all the brute forcing attempts have to be done on the device itself.

Nobody said apple.com you retarded sperg.

Apple was a front runner in implementing some sort of encryption long before others even thought about it. Apple uses a 256-bit device-unique secret key (UID) stored in the phone’s hardware, where it’s hard to extract from. Apple says this UID is unique to the device and it doesn’t store these values. It also says that no software or hardware can read this key. This UID is mixed with the passcode to generate a new key (passcode key) to secure data on the device. Unlike Android, this UID key can’t be extracted from the device, so all the brute forcing attempts have to be done on the device itself.

As per Apple, the content of a file is encrypted with a per-file key, which is wrapped with a class key and stored in a file’s metadata, which is in turn encrypted with the file system key. The class key is protected with the hardware UID and, for some classes, the user’s passcode. Here is a screenshot of the whole process. The new iOS 8 has only extended this feature to more items which are previously not encrypted – messages, pictures, etc.

https://resources.infosecinstitute.com/topic/understanding-disk-encryption-android-ios/

posts.com:
>>91472172
sudoedit doesn't just run the editor as root, that'd be hilariously insecure. It runs your editor on a temporary file, then it writes that temp file to the actual file. You need to go out of your way to mess that up. And sudo does.
What sudoedit does (see src/sudo_edit.c and plugins/sudoers/editor.c, correct me if I'm wrong) is take your $EDITOR, append --, append the files to edit, and then later read back from that by looking for -- in order to remember which files to edit.
So if you insert your own -- it finds your -- instead of the -- it added itself. It's not just unsanitized input, it's in-band signaling.
The right thing to do would have been to keep the editor and the file list separate until the very last minute. (Instead they slapped on the band-aid fix you describe. Which was reasonable under the circumstances.)
This smells like somebody tried to avoid allocating a whole other buffer out of laziness. In higher-level languages doing it right would have been less inconvenient.

wait...
but `editor` does not operate as root

what `sudoedit` does is:
1. copy the given file to a /var/tmp/file.xyz location
2. run "$EDITOR /var/tmp/file.xyz" *AS USER, NOT ROOT*
3. after editing, move /var/tmp/file.xyz back to original location

setting EDITOR to "vi -- /etc/passwd" makes it call:
"vi -- /etc/passwd /var/tmp/file.xyz"
so, yes, you are editing /etc/passwd, but AS USER!
and then unchanged /var/tmp/file.xyz is moved back

literally not a security issue at all

There's no reason $EDITOR needs to be trusted at all, unless you're doing something very strange.

That's what you'd think, but sudoedit does something really inane under the hood. See >>91472442.
When you run 
EDITOR='vi -- /etc/passwd' file.xyz
it validates that you're allowed to edit file.xyz, then it creates an array 
"vi" "--" "/etcpasswd" "--" "file.xyz"
, then it scans for the 
"--"
it just inserted and assumes that all the strings after that are files you're allowed to edit, and only then does it start creating temporary files.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91472831
You are not understanding what is _actually_ going on under the hood.
`sudoedit` is NOT a separate binary, it's a symlink to sudo
You're imagining that they are separate, modular binaries, they are not.
sudo has to parse it's command line arguments, and then decide what to do with it. It inspects argv[0] to decide what subaction to take.
In order to contextualize the arguments to know what to do with it, sudo must parse it's input. As a consequence it has to identify the files and editor command separately from the command line.
That's why your suggestion is not correct, sudo could just as easily identify files (to write with root permission) from $EDITOR if its not careful.
Because it's the same binary and same codebase as visudo, it NEEDS to do some parsing to keep it secure.
Hence why it makes no sense to keep the argument vector separate, and a keyword is a sensible solution.
You can argue that perhaps sudoedit and visudo should be their own binaries, sure. Then your solution makes *some* sense.
You can also argue that perhaps it shouldn't open anything at all in $EDITOR with root, even with visudo - allowing you to keep $EDITOR and argv separate - but this breaks some workflows and features.

The editor doesn't execute as root. If it did then all security would be lost automatically. The editor executes with your privileges on a tempfile.

>2>&1 is performed before $(echo foo >&2) is expanded
there are still ways to cheat this, like `>&2 echo a & echo b 2>&1 | grep -qx a` they don't necessarily need a causal connection when within subshells. how does this fare between various shells?
>some shells interpret &>/dev/null as >/dev/null 2>&1 even in POSIX mode
makes sense, I thought that was just an invalid construct. my theory is that all the shells doing this aim for bash compatibility over posix, likely because bash in posix mode had this issue, they cloned that issue for compatibility, and now we're in a deadlock. end result is indeed a fork in posix compatibility. but my point stands, you are better off parsing $editor in a shell than rolling your own word splitting and path expansion which may be completely different semantics from what the user expected when they composed the variable.

the command creates an explicit subshell for the first command to run in, which means the first has no relation to what redirects the other command performs. if bash subshelled for $() and waited for the return instead of running it locally, and in your scenario did the subshelling then only did it do the outer then inner redirect, it would still be valid unless posix has something else to say about this.

>>91503360

For what it's worth: I've wanted the Rust compiler to have opt-in telemetry since the very beginning of the project, long before Amazon had any interest in it. Even just knowing which errors users hit on a regular basis would be hugely valuable to the language developers.

I know "telemetry" sounds like "ad tracking spyware" or something nefarious, but in most cases it's literally just performance and error counters, and it tells the developers extremely valuable information about how their product is working (or not-working) in the field. It's one of the main reasons chrome did so well out of the gate relative to firefox: they could actually figure out what was working well or poorly for their users, rather than having to listen for indirect signals like angry forum posts.

- Little code fragments I want to store.
- I travel for work, a lot. I've got individual notes for an airport I visit (real address of car rental return, location of in-terminal clubs, places to eat, places to stay, not to stay)
- misc info I don't need now but when I need it, I need it NOW (car VIN, license info comes to mind)
- recipes
- checklists / todo lists
- shit to read later
- books to add to my reading list
All that stuff that I won't bother committing to memory but that I know I will want to retrieve later.

>>91479028
I use my text editor to write and read markdown files, which I keep on my nextcloud. If it's sensitive I may encrypt it with gpg or put it in a tomb (very good and lightweight encryption tool), but I generally find my provider trustworthy.
If I need to share the note, nextcloud lets me easily do that and renders markdown. Unfortunately it won't let me edit the file in my editor after that, only the nextcloud web editor. So I have to pass the website text buffer into my editor and edit it that way, it's a mess. But I rarely share notes.

I gave up on the fuckhuge stacks of tagged notes, I never go back to read most of them anyway. I just keep one well organized file for each topic and use filesystem path references for expansive lists.
I enjoy some of the emacs built-in suite, but don't like the editor so they don't work for me. Instead, I wrote some bash scripts to handle my journals, them being the only thing asking for more attention to policy than I can afford to expend as often as I write the entries. I'd share them, but some are among the first scripts I ever wrote, and frankly embarrassing.

Having a privacy policy for a clock app is important because it ensures that the app developer is transparent about how they use and handle any personal information collected from users. A privacy policy can include information about the types of data collected, how the data is stored and protected, who has access to the data, and how users can control the use of their personal information.

In addition, having a privacy policy is also a legal requirement in many countries, including under the European Union's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) and the California Consumer Privacy Act (CCPA). By having a privacy policy, the clock app is demonstrating its commitment to protecting the privacy of its users and adhering to relevant laws and regulations.

#include<stdlib.h>
#include<stdio.h>
#define STRINGVECTOR_STEPPING_SIZE 10
typedef struct{
  char* string;
  unsigned int size;
  unsigned int max_size;
} StringVector;
int StringVector_initialize(StringVector* newStringVector){
  newStringVector->string = malloc(sizeof(char) * STRINGVECTOR_STEPPING_SIZE);
  if(newStringVector == NULL){
    //unable to allocate memory. Out of memory?
    return -1;
  }
  newStringVector->size = 0;
  newStringVector->max_size = STRINGVECTOR_STEPPING_SIZE;
  #ifdef DEBUG
    printf("New StringVector created at: 0x%X
",newStringVector);
    printf("size: %d
",newStringVector->size);
    printf("max_size: %d
",newStringVector->max_size);
  #endif
  return 1;
}

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
int StringVector_appendString(StringVector* stringVector, char* newString){
  //if there's something already there, it has a \0, so remove that
  if(stringVector->size > 0){
    stringVector->size--;
  }
  //step through the newString, adding characters to stringVector->string
  //if stringVector->size reaches stringVector->max_size, reallocate it
  for(unsigned int index = 0; newString[index] != '\0'; index++){
    #ifdef DEBUG
      printf("Adding %c
",newString[index]);
    #endif
    stringVector->string[stringVector->size] = newString[index];
    stringVector->size++;
    if(stringVector->size == stringVector->max_size){
      //reallocate
      #ifdef DEBUG
        printf("Reallocating StringVector at: 0x%X
",stringVector->string);
      #endif
      char* reallocated_string = malloc((sizeof(char) * STRINGVECTOR_STEPPING_SIZE) + stringVector->max_size);
      if(reallocated_string == NULL){
        //unable to allocate memory, out of memory?
        return -1;
      }
      for(unsigned int reallocation_index = 0; reallocation_index < stringVector->max_size; reallocation_index++){
        reallocated_string[reallocation_index] = stringVector->string[reallocation_index];
      }
      free(stringVector->string);
      stringVector->string = reallocated_string;
      stringVector->max_size += STRINGVECTOR_STEPPING_SIZE;
      #ifdef DEBUG
        printf("StringVector reallocated and is at: 0x%X
",stringVector->string);
      #endif
    }
  }
  //by the time it reaches the end, the StringVector->size will have already been tested for StringVector->max_size,
  //  so it's safe to just append a \0. Worst case, it becomes max_size.
  stringVector->string[stringVector->size] = '\0';
  stringVector->size++;
  return 1;
}

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91488766
No. The language itself is fairly simple, but it requires more lines of code and more care to do stuff than in higher-level languages. If you're careless, you may create a segmentation fault or other error. It's not the end of the world though, there are debuggers and other tools which usually let you track down the cause easily.
/g/ has a lot of dumb contrarians so you shouldn't pay too much attention to that. It's just like the people who seethe about mechanical keyboards and try to argue that they're worse than rubber ones. It's pretty obvious most of them don't even have basic knowledge about C. We unfortunately have some Rust shills too.
Still, if you're new to programming I would start with Python. It's an easier first language and you'll write actually useful programs earlier in the learning process, which helps keep motivation up. C is a good choice for a second language after you're completely fluent with basic programming constructs like while loops and recursion, especially if you're interested in embedded or high-performance programming.
Do you want some book recommendations?

posts.name: Anonymous

>>91490253
Two introductory Python books that are completely free. The first covers more computer science knowledge, the second has more immediately practical stuff like reading data from Excel. You can mix and match chapters according to your interest.
>Think Python, 2nd Edition
>Automate the Boring Stuff with Python
If you end up liking Python, these two books will be useful later to take you from an intermediate level to proficiency.
>Effective Python
>Fluent Python
For C, this is my usual recommendation. Fairly well written, plus more up to date and less terse than K&R.
>C Programming: A Modern Approach
And here's a reference that's not as good as an introduction but it's useful to keep bookmarked as a reference.
>https://beej.us/guide/bgc/
And remember to practice a lot. Books are useful guides but you need to write projects to gain skill.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91491208
I've heard a lot of good things about Harvard and MIT's online courses so these are probably a decent place to start. I can't make a personal recommendation of anything though because I've always strongly preferred books to videos, especially if those books have exercises. Books are more information-dense, much easier to jump around in and cross-reference, and they let me vary my reading speed depending on whether it's new/difficult material or just a reminder of what I already know. I've also found that in a long lecture, it's easy to kind of passively nod along and later realize that I haven't retained most of the information. That said, it may just be me.
At the risk of repeating myself, I'll emphasize the importance of practice again. After you finish your first book/course or two, you should be spending most of the time in an editor, working on projects, not reading an endless stack of further books and certainly not on 4chan. Great books can provide advice that will cut your learning time by years, but your actual skill growth as a programmer happens when you put it in practice and tackle difficult problems. Don't be like picrel.

There seem to be three versions of Python, 1, 2 and 3. Should I focus on a specific one or there is no difference?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91502625
Python 1 is ancient and nobody writes it anymore, Python 2 is in the last stages of being phased out but it's still commonly installed for compatibility with old software, and Python 3 is the current version that most people use. You should write Python 3 and use learning materials that target Python 3. For example, if you're going to read the Think Python book, you want the second edition which uses Python 3, not the first edition which uses Python 2.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91500774
Blogging was indeed a popular and rapidly growing trend in the late 1990s and early 2000s. With the rise of social media platforms such as Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram, however, the popularity of personal blogging began to decline. These platforms offer a more convenient and immediate way for people to share their thoughts and experiences, and they also offer features that blogs do not, such as the ability to interact with friends and followers in real-time.

Additionally, the rise of smartphone usage and mobile internet access has made it easier for people to consume content on-the-go, making social media a more attractive option for many. This shift towards social media has led to a decrease in the number of people starting new blogs, and many bloggers who were active in the past have either abandoned their blogs or are updating them less frequently.

That being said, blogging is not dead and there are still many active bloggers who continue to write and maintain their blogs. While the popularity of blogging may have declined, it still serves as a platform for individuals to share their thoughts, experiences, and knowledge with the world, and for many, it remains an important part of the online community.

>>91501502
Yes, but a further weak spot is that the actual keys are protected by LSA secret - which is why they're blown away during a password reset as a security measure: you reset Administrator's password, then fire up something like mimikatz to access the non-reset user's (unaffected) LSA secrets (because you're an administrator now, you can do that), and (ab)use that.
It's why we moved to FVE in the first place, starting with encrypting the OS (and by extension, passwords, keys, etc.), because there isn't an easy way around this. Even with a SYSKEY, it's hard to protect against offline SAM editing.

posts.com:
>>91499747
There is a difference between encrypting a system drive and a regular hard drive with no OS present. With a system drive, it still has to be bootable, right? When you turn on the PC, the initialization process needs to see that there is an encrypted partition and an OS present. That lowers the security to a degree, since there is not just pure random shit on the drive (the chiffre = result of encryption), but also some marker for the bootloader to hook into and tell you "encrypted partition/OS found!".

The encrypted partition will always be there and readable by most programs that deal with this, so Bitlocker or not, Veracrypt and Zulucrypt should be able to see those, though you will not be able to boot it easily without the Windows capability.

As for regular HDDs with just files, these can be encrypted wholly (which is recommended for multiple reasons) and then unencrypted with any program that has that respective method built in. Bitlocker is backdoored though, as MS/NSA have the keys to the castle there.

import os
import subprocess as sp
import shutil

in_dir = os.getenv('in_dir', os.getcwd())
minbitrate = os.getenv('minbitrate', '2500k')
maxbitrate = os.getenv('maxbitrate', '5000k')

for fname in os.listdir(in_dir):

        arglist = ['-i', fname, '-c:v',

                   #etc
                   newname]
        print(' '.join(arglist))
        sp.call([ffmpeg] + arglist)

fixed path
import os
import subprocess as sp
import shutil

in_dir = os.getenv('in_dir', os.getcwd())
minbitrate = os.getenv('minbitrate', '2500k')
maxbitrate = os.getenv('maxbitrate', '5000k')

ffmpeg = shutil.which('ffpmeg')

for fname in os.listdir(in_dir):
    if fname.endswith('.avs'):
        oldname = os.path.join(in_dir, fname)
        newname = oldname[:-4] + '.mp4'
        arglist = ['-i', oldname, '-c:v',
                   #etc
                   minbitrate, '-maxrate:v', maxbitrate,
                   #etc
                   newname]
        print(' '.join(arglist))
        sp.call([ffmpeg] + arglist)

for vid in $0/*.avs; do

        -c:v h264_nvenc -rc:v vbr_hq \
        -cq:v 19 -b:v "$1" -maxrate:v "$2" \
        -preset llhq -profile:v high \
        "$(basename "$vid" .avs).mp4"
done

#!/usr/bin/env python3

import os
import subprocess

in_dir = os.getenv('in_dir', '.')
min_bitrate = os.getenv('min_bitrate', '2500k')
max_bitrate = os.getenv('max_bitrate', '5000k')

for fname in os.listdir(in_dir):
    fname_no_ext, fname_ext = os.path.splitext(fname)
    if fname.endswith('.avs'):
        old_path = os.path.join(in_dir, fname)
        new_path = os.path.join(in_dir, fname_no_ext + '.mp4')
        subprocess.run([
            'ffmpeg', '-i', old_path,
            '-c:v', min_bitrate, '-maxrate:v', max_bitrate,
            new_path])

srcdir=$1
minrate=$2
maxrate=$3

for src in "$srcdir"/*.avs; do
    dest=${src%.*}.mp4
    args=(
        -i "$src"
        -c:v h264_nvenc
        -rc:v vbr_hq
        -cq:v 19
        -b:v "$minrate"
        -maxrate:v "$maxrate"
        -preset llhq
        -profile:v high
    )

    printf '\e[32m%s %s\e[m\n' "${args[@]}"
    printf '\e[32m%s\e[m\n' "$dest"

    ffmpeg "${args[@]}" "$dest"
done

#!/usr/bin/perl
use strict;
use warnings;
use v5.10;
use Term::ANSIColor qw(:constants);

my ($in_dir, $minbitrate, $maxbitrate) = @ARGV;
my @videos = glob qq{ "$in_dir"/*avs };

for my $vid (@videos) {
    my $new_video = $vid =~ s/\.avs$/.mp4/r;

    my $cmd = qq{
        ffmpeg
        -i          "$vid"
        -c:v        h264_nvenc
        -rc:v       vbr_hq
        -cq:v       19
        -b:v        $minbitrate
        -maxrate:v  $maxbitrate
        -preset     llhq
        -profile:v  high
        "$new_video"

    } =~ s/^\s*//r =~ s{ (" (?: [^\\"] | \\. )* ") | \s+ }{ $1 // " " }gxer;

#   } =~ s/^\s*//r =~ s/\s+/ /gr; # ==> doesn't handle "./file with    spaces.mp4"

    say GREEN, $cmd, RESET;
    system $cmd;
}

>>91496569
usually the 2 part of s/// is for the replacement string, but with the /e modifier, you can put arbitrary code which will be evaluated and the result will be stringified and used as a replacement
so,
if match a double quoted string, then the capturing group number 1 is defined and returns it
else, match several whitespace, capturing group 1 is not set, $1 is undefined and we replace the whitespaces with 1 space

basically, if we do this 
s/\s+/ /g
but leave the double quoted string as they are (to not mess with files containing spaces)
also, the regex match double quoted strings and accounts for escaping characters

Thread challenge!

Pick one of the following:

* Add the name of a Yu-Gi-Oh! card into your prompt.
If you don't know what I'm talking about, or just can't bother choosing, use this:
https://yugipedia.com/wiki/Special:Random

* Use picrel and apply your recent prompt on it via img2img, on 70 or more denoise. Do the whole thing, not panel by panel!
Bonus: Add tags that alter the medium like "comic book" or "manga page".

* Take your recent prompt, take the negative prompt and now use it as the positive prompt. You can now do anything with the new negative prompt to make a cool pic.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91502151
Both at different times.
When the model loads initially, that's your disk speed which will throttle it. Once it's loaded it's moved into VRAM and until you swap model or close the UI it won't access the disk.
Similarly when you generate images, they're stored in RAM until the batch is complete then they're all written onto the hard drive at the end.

i have it set up to load off a different drive
>set COMMANDLINE_ARGS=--ckpt-dir "Z:\MODELS" --xformers --lora-dir "Z:\LORA" --no-half-vae

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91492784
It was fairly easy, hardest part is removing the glass back without breaking it. Fortunately, the one with a dead mainboard came without a glass back and the broken screen one also had a broken back, so I didn't have to be careful with them. Got a cyberpunk edition back glass from ali. Rest is just swapping the mainboards and testing both batteries to see which one is better(one was ~92% health, the other one ~80%). It will take maybe about 2-3 hours of work if you have no previous experience(without counting the time required to test both batteries).

For this to make sense economically speaking you need to find well priced offers for such ''part only'' phones though, which is a rare opportunity. I got a bargain on the 8T with the dead board which costed me just 44 euros with the shipping and planned the rest of the project around that. Sourcing a broken 8T with 12/256 board took a lot of searching.
